name: Bodhi Tree

sections.content: The sacred fig tree (Ficus religiosa) under which Siddhartha Gautama attained enlightenment and became the Buddha. The original tree in Bodh Gaya is one of Buddhism's most sacred sites, representing the axis mundi of Buddhist cosmology.
sections.title: Description

symbolicMeanings: Heart-shaped leaves = compassion and Buddha-nature
Deep roots = groundedness in dharma
Spreading canopy = protection and refuge
Constant movement of leaves = impermanence
Fig fruits = sweetness of enlightenment

hoverInfo.quick: The sacred fig tree (Ficus religiosa) under which Siddhartha Gautama attained enlightenment and beca...

listDisplay.expandedContent: The sacred fig tree (Ficus religiosa) under which Siddhartha Gautama attained enlightenment and became the Buddha. The original tree in Bodh Gaya is one of Buddhism's most sacred sites, representing the axis mundi of Buddhist cosmology.
listDisplay.secondary: The sacred fig tree (Ficus religiosa) under which Siddhartha Gautama attained enlightenment and beca...

sacredSignificance: Most sacred tree in Buddhism. Site of Buddha's enlightenment under full moon of Vesak. Represents the possibility of awakening for all beings. Direct descendants of original tree exist worldwide.
culturalContext: Emperor Ashoka's daughter Sanghamitta brought cutting to Sri Lanka in 288 BCE, now oldest verified tree. Bodhi tree cuttings spread Buddhism across Asia. Heart-shaped leaves symbolize Buddha-nature in all beings.
description: The sacred fig tree (Ficus religiosa) under which Siddhartha Gautama attained enlightenment and became the Buddha. The original tree in Bodh Gaya is one of Buddhism's most sacred sites, representing the axis mundi of Buddhist cosmology.
safetyWarnings: fig latex may cause skin irritation in sensitive individuals

etymology.derivation: From Sanskrit bodhi (‡§¨‡•ã‡§ß‡§ø), from budh (to awaken)

preparationMethods: Medicinal decoction: boil bark in water for digestive issues
Leaf powder: dry leaves, grind to powder for wounds
Poultice: crush fresh leaves for anti-inflammatory application
Sacred offerings: place flowers and incense at tree base
rituals: Bodhi Day (Dec 8) - commemorating Buddha's enlightenment
Circumambulation - walk clockwise around bodhi trees with prayers
Leaf offerings - placing gold leaf on bodhi leaves as offering
Temple consecration - planting bodhi tree sanctifies temple grounds
Meditation retreats - extended practice under bodhi trees
uses: Meditation - sit beneath bodhi trees to invoke enlightenment energy
Pilgrimage - Bodh Gaya bodhi tree descended from original enlightenment tree
Temple planting - every major Buddhist temple plants bodhi tree
Bodhi leaf amulets - carry dried leaves for spiritual protection
Offerings - water bodhi trees as act of merit and devotion

name: Lotus
rituals: Daily offerings - fresh lotus to Buddha images
Vesak celebrations - lotus lamps floated on water
Meditation practice - lotus position (padmasana)
Visualization - opening thousand-petaled crown chakra lotus
Funeral rites - lotus symbolizes rebirth in Pure Land

colorSymbolism.red: Compassion, love, passion, heart chakra, Avalokiteshvara
colorSymbolism.blue: Wisdom, knowledge, victory over senses, Manjushri
colorSymbolism.pink: Supreme lotus, Buddha himself, historical Buddha
colorSymbolism.white: Mental and spiritual purity, Bodhi (perfect enlightenment)

symbolicMeanings: Roots in mud = grounded in reality of suffering
Stem through water = journey through samsara
Flower above water = enlightenment transcending worldly attachment
Unopened bud = potential for awakening
Fully open = perfect enlightenment
Lotus closes at night, opens at dawn = death and rebirth cycle
sacredSignificance: Central symbol of Buddhism. Buddha born with lotus appearing at each step. Lotus throne represents transcendence. Emergence from mud = enlightenment possible despite samsara. Pure Land Buddhism: rebirth in lotus of Amitabha's paradise.
safetyWarnings: generally safe as food and tea
ensure clean water source if wild-harvesting
preparationMethods: Lotus seed tea: simmer dried seeds for calming nervousness
Lotus root: slice and cook for nutrition and lung health
Lotus petal tea: steep dried petals for aromatic calming tea
Stamens: dry and use in tea blends for heart health
Seed paste: grind seeds for mooncake filling (spiritual festivals)
uses: Buddha statues - seated on lotus throne (padmasana)
Mantra visualization - Om Mani Padme Hum (jewel in the lotus)
Meditation - contemplate lotus emergence from mud as path metaphor
Temple offerings - fresh lotus flowers offered daily
Iconography - lotus held by bodhisattvas symbolizes compassion
culturalContext: Every part of lotus used: seeds (longevity), roots (nutrition), petals (beauty), stamens (tea). Lotus ponds essential at Buddhist temples. Ancient symbol predating Buddhism, adopted and elevated by dharma.
description: The lotus flower symbolizes purity, enlightenment, and spiritual awakening in Buddhism. It grows from mud yet remains unstained, representing the potential for enlightenment within samsara. Different colored lotuses carry distinct spiritual meanings.

listDisplay.expandedContent: The lotus flower symbolizes purity, enlightenment, and spiritual awakening in Buddhism. It grows from mud yet remains unstained, representing the potential for enlightenment within samsara. Different colored lotuses carry distinct spiritual meanings.
listDisplay.secondary: The lotus flower symbolizes purity, enlightenment, and spiritual awakening in Buddhism. It grows fro...

sections.content: The lotus flower symbolizes purity, enlightenment, and spiritual awakening in Buddhism. It grows from mud yet remains unstained, representing the potential for enlightenment within samsara. Different colored lotuses carry distinct spiritual meanings.
sections.title: Description

hoverInfo.quick: The lotus flower symbolizes purity, enlightenment, and spiritual awakening in Buddhism. It grows fro...

sacredSignificance: One of three sacred incenses (with agarwood and clove). Fragrance attracts bodhisattvas and dakinis. Buddha's body said to emanate sandalwood fragrance. Cooling nature calms passions, aids meditation. Supreme offering to Triple Gem.
description: Sacred fragrant heartwood used extensively in Buddhist incense, meditation, and rituals. Its calming, cooling scent aids concentration, purifies the mind and environment, and is believed to attract enlightened beings.
preparationMethods: Incense: burn wood chips or powder on charcoal
Essential oil: steam distillation (very expensive)
Sacred paste: grind wood with water on stone to make paste
Mala beads: carve from heartwood for meditation
Powder: grind aged heartwood to fine powder for offerings
Hydrosol: sandalwood water for anointing and cooling

hoverInfo.quick: Sacred fragrant heartwood used extensively in Buddhist incense, meditation, and rituals. Its calming...

name: Sandalwood

growingConditions.conservation: Critically endangered - cultivation and sustainable harvest essential

symbolicMeanings: Fragrance = virtue spreading naturally
Cooling = calming afflictive emotions
Heartwood = inner purity and value
Longevity = patience and gradual development
Precious = dharma treasures beyond worldly wealth

listDisplay.expandedContent: Sacred fragrant heartwood used extensively in Buddhist incense, meditation, and rituals. Its calming, cooling scent aids concentration, purifies the mind and environment, and is believed to attract enlightened beings.
listDisplay.secondary: Sacred fragrant heartwood used extensively in Buddhist incense, meditation, and rituals. Its calming...

culturalContext: Mysore sandalwood (Karnataka, India) most prized. Critically endangered due to over-harvesting. Australian sandalwood (S. spicatum) sustainable alternative. Temple-quality sandalwood extremely expensive. Adulteration common - pure sandalwood rare.
rituals: Daily puja - sandalwood incense essential temple offering
Meditation practice - burn before and during sitting
Blessing ceremonies - anoint with sandalwood paste
Funeral rites - cremate with sandalwood (traditional)
Abhisheka - anoint Buddha statues with sandalwood water
Monastic ordination - receive sandalwood mala
uses: Meditation incense - calms mind, deepens concentration
Prayer beads (mala) - sandalwood malas aid mantra practice
Sacred paste - ground sandalwood mixed with water for tilak marks
Buddha statues - precious statues carved from sandalwood
Funeral rites - burned to guide consciousness in bardo
Temple fragrance - burned daily to purify sacred space
safetyWarnings: generally safe for external use and aromatherapy
pure essential oil expensive - beware adulteration

sections.title: Description
sections.content: Sacred fragrant heartwood used extensively in Buddhist incense, meditation, and rituals. Its calming, cooling scent aids concentration, purifies the mind and environment, and is believed to attract enlightened beings.

name: Tea (Cha)
uses: Meditation aid - enhances alertness during zazen
Tea ceremony (Chanoyu) - Way of Tea spiritual practice
Daily monastic practice - consumed throughout day in temples
L-theanine + caffeine = calm focus perfect for meditation
Green tea (matcha) for ceremonial use
sacredSignificance: Tea and Zen are 'one taste' (Cha Zen Ichimi). Bodhidharma legend: his eyelids became first tea plants to aid meditation. Essential to Zen Buddhist practice.
preparationMethods: Matcha: whisk powder in hot water (70-80¬∞C) until frothy
Sencha: steep loose leaves 1-2 minutes
Gongfu cha: multiple short steeps in small teapot
Temple style: large pot of light green tea served communally

buddhist.usage: Central to Zen/Chan practice. Japanese tea ceremony (Chado) is spiritual discipline. Every Zen temple has tea practice.
buddhist.significance: Symbolizes mindfulness, impermanence, simplicity. Meditation and tea inseparable.

chinese.usage: Chan Buddhist temples, Gongfu tea ceremony
chinese.significance: Aid to meditation, represents middle way between sleep and agitation

tibetan.usage: Butter tea (po cha) with salt and yak butter
tibetan.significance: Daily staple in monasteries, warming and energizing

description: Tea (Cha) is a figure from ancient mythology.

symbolicMeanings: Closing at night = death, underworld journey
Opening at dawn = resurrection, Ra's rebirth
Blue color = Nile, sky, creation waters
Sweet fragrance = divine breath and life force (ka)
Rising from mud = purity emerging from chaos
Thousand petals = infinite creative potential

listDisplay.secondary: The sacred blue water lily of ancient Egypt, symbol of the sun, creation, and rebirth. Its flowers c...
listDisplay.expandedContent: The sacred blue water lily of ancient Egypt, symbol of the sun, creation, and rebirth. Its flowers close at night and sink underwater, rising and reopening with the dawn sun. Associated with Ra, Nefertem, and the primordial creation.

growingConditions.native: Nile Delta and tropical East Africa

name: Blue Lotus
uses: Temple offerings - fresh lotus offered daily to Ra and solar deities
Funerary art - lotus motifs on tombs, sarcophagi, papyri
Ceremonial wine - lotus flowers steeped in wine for sacred intoxication
Perfume and oils - lotus essence in sacred anointing oils
Meditation and vision - mild psychoactive properties for religious experiences
Banquet decoration - lotus wreaths and garlands at festivals

sections.content: The sacred blue water lily of ancient Egypt, symbol of the sun, creation, and rebirth. Its flowers close at night and sink underwater, rising and reopening with the dawn sun. Associated with Ra, Nefertem, and the primordial creation.
sections.title: Description

safetyWarnings: may enhance effects of alcohol and sedatives
quality varies greatly - source from reputable suppliers
sacredSignificance: Supreme solar symbol. Nefertem = 'lotus emerging from primordial waters.' Pharaohs depicted smelling lotus = divine breath and vitality. Tutankhamun's tomb filled with lotus wreaths. Represents emergence of cosmos from Nun (primordial waters).
rituals: Morning sun rituals - opening lotus = Ra's rebirth each dawn
Funerary rites - lotus placed on mummies and in tombs
New Year festivals - lotus offered at Wepet-Renpet
Birth ceremonies - lotus symbolizes new life emerging
Coronation rites - pharaohs depicted with lotus (kingship and divinity)
Temple purification - lotus water sprinkled for cleansing
preparationMethods: Lotus wine: steep 5-10 fresh flowers in red wine 2 weeks
Lotus tea: 5g dried flowers in hot water 10-15 minutes
Smoking blend: dried petals and stamens (traditional)
Tincture: alcohol extraction for concentrated effects
Ritual bath: float fresh flowers in sacred bath water
Essential oil: rare and expensive, via solvent extraction
description: The sacred blue water lily of ancient Egypt, symbol of the sun, creation, and rebirth. Its flowers close at night and sink underwater, rising and reopening with the dawn sun. Associated with Ra, Nefertem, and the primordial creation.

activeConstituents.effects: Mild relaxation, dream enhancement, gentle euphoria, heightened awareness

legalStatus: Legal in most countries but banned in some (e.g., Poland, Russia, Latvia). Check local regulations.
culturalContext: Omnipresent in Egyptian art, architecture, jewelry. Column capitals shaped like lotus buds and flowers. Hieroglyph for Upper Egypt. Lotus and papyrus together = unified Egypt. Ancient wine and beer infused with lotus for ceremonial use.

hoverInfo.quick: The sacred blue water lily of ancient Egypt, symbol of the sun, creation, and rebirth. Its flowers c...

metadata.note: Mythological substance with no botanical equivalent

culturalContext: Ambrosia and nectar sometimes used interchangeably, sometimes distinguished (ambrosia = solid food, nectar = drink). No mortal knows true recipe. Symbol of unattainable divine perfection. Cautionary tales warn against stealing it.
mythologicalOrigins: Garden of Hesperides - grown in sacred groves guarded by nymphs
Mount Olympus - distilled from the pure ether of upper air
Divine creation - crafted through secret godly arts unknown to mortals
Sacred springs - flows from hidden fountains on Olympus
Divine bees - produced by supernatural bees from celestial flowers
Gift of Gaia - earth mother's gift to her divine children

listDisplay.secondary: The legendary food of the Olympian gods, granting immortality and eternal youth to those who consume...
listDisplay.expandedContent: The legendary food of the Olympian gods, granting immortality and eternal youth to those who consume it. Described as nine times sweeter than honey, with incomparable fragrance. Mortals who taste ambrosia become immortal - or die from its divine potency.

mythologicalAppearance.color: Golden, radiant, honey-like or ethereal white
mythologicalAppearance.texture: Varies - sometimes liquid nectar, sometimes solid like honey or food
mythologicalAppearance.fragrance: Incomparably aromatic, perfumes all of Olympus
mythologicalAppearance.effect: Fills gods with vitality, joy, and divine power
mythologicalAppearance.taste: Nine times sweeter than finest honey, indescribably delicious

symbolicMeanings: Divine essence beyond mortal comprehension
Immortality and eternal youth
Perfection unattainable by mortals
Sacred nourishment vs. earthly food
The gift of gods withheld from humanity
Transformation and transcendence
Divine beauty and radiance

hoverInfo.quick: The legendary food of the Olympian gods, granting immortality and eternal youth to those who consume...

sections.content: The legendary food of the Olympian gods, granting immortality and eternal youth to those who consume it. Described as nine times sweeter than honey, with incomparable fragrance. Mortals who taste ambrosia become immortal - or die from its divine potency.
sections.title: Description

name: Ambrosia
uses: Daily divine sustenance - primary food of Olympian gods
Preservation - Achilles' body anointed with ambrosia to prevent decay
Healing divine wounds - restores gods injured in battle
Conferring immortality - transforms mortals into immortals (rare)
Sacred horses - fed to divine steeds of gods
Anointing - used to purify and empower divine beings
Beauty enhancement - gods and goddesses use as divine cosmetic
preparationMethods: Unknown to mortals - divine mystery
Speculation: distilled from ether of upper air
Myth: gathered from sacred gardens by divine beings
Legend: created through divine theurgy beyond mortal comprehension

philosophicalInterpretation.symbolic: The eternal, unchanging realm of Forms (Platonic)
philosophicalInterpretation.mystical: Sacred gnosis transforming human to divine consciousness

sacredSignificance: Defines the immortal/mortal boundary. Consumption = transformation to divine state. Symbol of divine privilege and eternal life. Contrasts with mortal bread and wine. Represents the unbridgeable gap between gods and humans - yet also possibility of apotheosis.
mythologicalAccounts: Odyssey: Calypso offers Odysseus immortality via ambrosia (he refuses)
Iliad: Achilles' body preserved with ambrosia and nectar after death
Tantalus: Punished for stealing ambrosia to share with mortals
Demophon: Demeter fed infant ambrosia to make him immortal
Psyche: Ate ambrosia at wedding to Eros, became goddess
Dionysus: Fed ambrosia as infant after rescue from Semele's death
description: The legendary food of the Olympian gods, granting immortality and eternal youth to those who consume it. Described as nine times sweeter than honey, with incomparable fragrance. Mortals who taste ambrosia become immortal - or die from its divine potency.
safetyWarnings: MYTHOLOGICAL ONLY - no earthly equivalent exists
Ancient warnings: mortals who taste ambrosia either become immortal or die
Theft of ambrosia punished severely (see Tantalus)
For study of mythology and symbolism only

name: Tulsi (Holy Basil)
uses: Daily worship (nitya puja) - watered and circumambulated every morning
Tulsi Vivah - ceremonial marriage to Shaligram/Vishnu
Puja offerings - essential to Vishnu/Krishna worship
Tulsi tea - Ayurvedic adaptogen for stress and immunity
Sacred tulsi leaves in prasad and holy water
sacredSignificance: Most sacred plant in Hinduism. Living manifestation of Lakshmi. Vrinda Devi transformed into Tulsi. Every Hindu household worships Tulsi plant daily. No Vishnu puja complete without Tulsi leaves.
preparationMethods: Tulsi tea: 5-7 fresh leaves or 1 tsp dried, simmer 5-10 minutes
Tulsi-honey remedy: crush leaves, mix with honey and black pepper for colds
Tulsi powder (churna): 1/4-1/2 tsp with warm water daily
Fresh leaves: chewed directly or added to water
safetyWarnings: avoid large medicinal doses during pregnancy

hindu.usage: Daily worship in household shrine (tulsi vrindavan). Tulsi Vivah festival. Essential puja offering.
hindu.significance: Goddess Lakshmi resides in Tulsi. Purifies home, brings prosperity, spiritual protection. Beloved of Krishna.

ayurvedic.usage: Rasayana (rejuvenative), adaptogen, immune tonic, respiratory support
ayurvedic.significance: Balances all three doshas. Promotes longevity and spiritual vitality.

description: Tulsi (Holy Basil) is a figure from ancient mythology.

name: Hyssop (Ezov)
uses: Passover - applied lamb's blood to doorposts with hyssop bunch
Red Heifer purification - essential in creating purification waters
Tzaraat cleansing - ritual purification from spiritual impurity
Temple incense (Ketoret) - component of sacred incense blend
Psalm 51:7 - 'Purge me with hyssop and I shall be clean'
sacredSignificance: Biblical purification plant. Used in most important Jewish purification rituals. Symbolizes humility (grows from walls). Essential to Temple service. Represents divine cleansing and forgiveness.
preparationMethods: Biblical bundle: tied together, dipped in blood or purification water
Hyssop tea: 1-2 tsp dried leaves per cup, steep 10 minutes
Za'atar blend: primary ingredient in Middle Eastern spice mix
Not used ritually since Temple destruction (70 CE)
safetyWarnings: essential oil toxic - do not ingest

jewish.usage: Temple purification, red heifer ritual, Passover blood application, tzaraat cleansing
jewish.significance: Symbol of humility and divine purification. Contrasted with cedar (pride) in rituals.

christian.usage: Vinegar offered to Jesus on hyssop branch at crucifixion
christian.significance: Connects to Passover lamb imagery, baptismal purification symbolism

kabbalistic.significance: Associated with Chesed (loving-kindness) and divine mercy washing away sin

description: Hyssop (Ezov) is a figure from ancient mythology.

name: Mandrake (Dudaim)
uses: HISTORICAL STUDY ONLY - DO NOT USE
Genesis 30: Rachel and Leah bargain for mandrakes
Song of Solomon: erotic imagery with mandrakes
Historical (dangerous): fertility charm, love magic, anesthetic
sacredSignificance: Biblical love and fertility plant. Rachel desperately wanted mandrakes for fertility, but Leah (not Rachel) conceived instead - teaching that fertility comes from God, not herbs. Symbolizes human desire vs divine will.
preparationMethods: DO NOT PREPARE - HIGHLY TOXIC
Contains tropane alkaloids (scopolamine, atropine, hyoscyamine)
Can cause delirium, hallucinations, seizures, coma, death
This entry is for HISTORICAL and MYTHOLOGICAL study ONLY
safetyWarnings: No safe dose - can be fatal
Keep away from children and pets

jewish.usage: Biblical narrative (Genesis 30, Song of Solomon). Not used in practice.
jewish.significance: Lesson that fertility is divine gift, not magical result. Symbol of love and desire.

greek.usage: Myth of Myrrha/Adonis. Historical surgical anesthetic (dangerous).
greek.significance: Transformation, tears of sorrow becoming healing (mythology)

folklore.usage: Screaming root legend, dog harvesting method, anthropomorphic root
folklore.significance: Dangerous power requiring special knowledge to harvest

description: Mandrake (Dudaim) is a figure from ancient mythology.

sacredSignificance: Yggdrasil = existence itself. All Nine Realms exist within/upon tree. While tree lives, cosmos endures. Odin's sacrifice on Yggdrasil = supreme act of wisdom-seeking. Tree embodies interconnection of all life, fate, time, and space.

cosmology.threeLevels: Upper (Asgard, Vanaheim, Alfheim), Middle (Midgard, Jotunheim, Svartalfheim, Nidavellir), Lower (Helheim, Niflheim, Muspelheim)
cosmology.structure: Ash tree of cosmic proportions with three roots and three wells

hoverInfo.quick: The immense cosmic ash tree at the center of Norse cosmology, connecting all Nine Realms from roots ...

nineRealms.helheim: Realm of the dead - deep roots (sometimes counted separately from Niflheim)
nineRealms.svartalfheim: Realm of dark elves - below surface
nineRealms.alfheim: Realm of light elves - upper regions
nineRealms.muspelheim: Realm of fire - roots in primordial flame
nineRealms.asgard: Realm of Aesir gods - upper branches
nineRealms.niflheim: Realm of ice and mist - roots in primordial cold
nineRealms.vanaheim: Realm of Vanir gods - upper roots/branches

ritualUses: Meditation on Nine Realms - journey through cosmic structure
Rune work - connecting to Odin's rune revelation
Ancestor veneration - connecting through roots to those who came before
Seeking wisdom - following Odin's example of sacrifice for knowledge

sections.content: The immense cosmic ash tree at the center of Norse cosmology, connecting all Nine Realms from roots to crown. Home to gods, humans, giants, elves, dwarves, and the dead. Constantly gnawed by Nidhogg (dragon), watered by Norns, visited by Odin's ravens, and will fall at Ragnar√∂k.
sections.title: Description

metadata.note: Cosmological concept rather than botanical plant, but included in herbs as sacred tree

etymology.derivation: Yggr (Odin's name) + drasill (horse) = the tree Odin 'rode' when hanging for nine nights

primarySources: Gr√≠mnism√°l - details of Nine Realms, wells, inhabitants
Gylfaginning (Prose Edda) - Snorri's compilation of Yggdrasil lore

modernInterpretations.ecological: Web of life, interconnection of all ecosystems, earth system
modernInterpretations.jungian: Collective unconscious, Self, wholeness, individuation journey
modernInterpretations.spiritual: Meditation on cosmic interconnection, shamanic world-walking

safetyWarnings: Yggdrasil is mythological/cosmological concept, not physical plant
Shamanic practices require training and guidance
Do not imitate Odin's hanging - symbolic spiritual ordeal only
This entry for mythological study and spiritual contemplation

threeWells.wellOfUrd: Norns water Yggdrasil's roots daily, determine fate of all beings
threeWells.mimirWell: Odin sacrificed eye for drink of wisdom from this well
threeWells.hvergelmir: Primordial spring where Nidhogg gnaws roots, source of rivers of existence

mythologicalEvents.ragnarok: Yggdrasil will shake violently but survive world's ending
mythologicalEvents.mimirSacrifice: Odin gave eye at Mimir's well beneath Yggdrasil for wisdom
mythologicalEvents.odinsVigil: Odin hung himself on Yggdrasil nine nights, pierced by spear, to gain runes
mythologicalEvents.runicRevelation: Runes revealed to Odin during his hanging ordeal
mythologicalEvents.rebirth: Tree endures Ragnar√∂k, shelters Lif and Lifthrasir (new humanity)

culturalContext: Central image of Norse cosmology preserved in Poetic Edda (V√∂lusp√°, Gr√≠mnism√°l) and Prose Edda. World tree concept appears across many cultures (Cosmic Tree archetype). Vikings understood existence as interconnected through Yggdrasil. Modern Heathenry maintains Yggdrasil cosmology.

threeRoots.secondRoot: Extends to Jotunheim - Mimir's Well (wisdom and knowledge)
threeRoots.thirdRoot: Extends to Niflheim - Hvergelmir (roaring cauldron, source of all rivers)
threeRoots.firstRoot: Extends to Asgard - Well of Urd (Norns' well of fate)

symbolicMeanings: Roots = past, ancestors, deep unconscious, underworld
Trunk = present, Midgard, everyday reality, humans
Branches = future, gods, higher consciousness, heaven
Constant gnawing = entropy, time, decay threatening existence
Daily watering = maintenance, care, renewal, choice
Eagle and dragon = cosmic duality, upper and lower, spirit and matter
Ratatosk = communication, discord, connection between extremes
Endurance through Ragnar√∂k = eternal nature of cosmic structure
description: The immense cosmic ash tree at the center of Norse cosmology, connecting all Nine Realms from roots to crown. Home to gods, humans, giants, elves, dwarves, and the dead. Constantly gnawed by Nidhogg (dragon), watered by Norns, visited by Odin's ravens, and will fall at Ragnar√∂k.

listDisplay.expandedContent: The immense cosmic ash tree at the center of Norse cosmology, connecting all Nine Realms from roots to crown. Home to gods, humans, giants, elves, dwarves, and the dead. Constantly gnawed by Nidhogg (dragon), watered by Norns, visited by Odin's ravens, and will fall at Ragnar√∂k.
listDisplay.secondary: The immense cosmic ash tree at the center of Norse cosmology, connecting all Nine Realms from roots ...

name: Yggdrasil - The World Tree

shamanicSignificance.worldAxis: Vertical shamanic axis for ascending to heaven or descending to underworld
shamanicSignificance.ancestorConnection: Tree connects living with ancestors and yet-to-be-born
shamanicSignificance.seidrTravel: V√∂lvas and shamans journey along Yggdrasil between realms
shamanicSignificance.runeQuest: Ultimate shamanic ordeal gaining cosmic wisdom
shamanicSignificance.odinsJourney: Odin's nine-night hanging = shamanic death and rebirth initiation

name: Frankincense (Olibanum)
uses: Temple incense - burned daily in Egyptian, Jewish, Christian temples
Gift of the Magi - presented to infant Jesus (symbolizing divinity)
Meditation and prayer - elevates consciousness, deepens practice
Arthritis treatment - boswellic acids reduce inflammation
Consecration - purifies ritual tools and sacred spaces
sacredSignificance: Most sacred incense across world religions. Carries prayers to heaven. Symbolizes divinity, purity, worship. Essential to temple service in Judaism, Christianity, Hinduism, Buddhism. One of three gifts to Christ.
preparationMethods: Incense: burn resin on charcoal disc
Essential oil: diffuse 5-10 drops for aromatherapy
Topical: dilute essential oil 2-5% in carrier oil
Internal: standardized extract 300-500mg boswellic acids 2-3x daily
Tincture: alcohol extract of resin
safetyWarnings: avoid large internal doses during pregnancy

egyptian.usage: Daily temple offerings to Ra, Isis, Osiris. Mummification. Kyphi incense blend.
egyptian.significance: Divine fragrance, preserves bodies and souls, connects to solar deity

jewish.usage: Ketoret (sacred temple incense). Showbread offering. Daily altar incense.
jewish.significance: Ascending smoke represents prayers rising to God. Pure frankincense symbolizes purity.

christian.usage: Gift of Magi (divinity). Catholic/Orthodox Mass. Consecration ceremonies.
christian.significance: Christ's divine nature, priestly role. Prayer and worship ascending.

islamic.usage: Mosque fumigation, Ramadan, wedding ceremonies, Quranic recitation

description: Frankincense (Olibanum) is a figure from ancient mythology.

name: Myrrh
uses: Egyptian mummification - primary preservative resin
Holy Anointing Oil - main ingredient (Exodus 30:23)
Gift of Magi - symbolized Christ's mortality and sacrifice
Burial of Jesus - Nicodemus brought 75 pounds myrrh and aloes
Wound healing - powerful antiseptic and tissue regenerator
Oral health - mouthwash for gingivitis and periodontitis
sacredSignificance: Sacred resin of death and healing. Bridges life and death, suffering and transformation. Third gift to Christ (mortality). Essential to mummification. Bitter medicine that heals. Death leading to rebirth.
preparationMethods: Tincture: 1/3 cup crushed resin in 1 cup high-proof alcohol, 4-6 weeks
Mouthwash: 5-10 drops tincture in 1/4 cup water, swish and gargle
Incense: burn resin on charcoal for death work, protection, ancestor veneration
Topical: dilute essential oil 1-5% in carrier oil for wounds
Salve: infused oil + beeswax for wound healing
safetyWarnings: AVOID DURING PREGNANCY - uterine stimulant, can cause miscarriage

egyptian.usage: Mummification (body cavities, wrapping). Temple incense. Cosmetics.
egyptian.significance: Preserves bodies for afterlife. Protects soul's journey through underworld.

jewish.usage: Holy Anointing Oil (primary ingredient). Wedding perfume. Esther's beauty treatment.
jewish.significance: Sacred consecration. Anoints kings, priests, prophets. Song of Solomon love imagery.

christian.usage: Gift of Magi (mortality). Wine+myrrh offered at crucifixion. Burial preparation.
christian.significance: Prophesied suffering and death. Bitter cup of sacrifice. Death transformed to resurrection.

chinese.usage: Mo Yao (Ê≤°ËçØ) - invigorates blood, dispels stasis, relieves pain
chinese.significance: Treats traumatic injury, blood stagnation, chest/abdominal pain

greek.usage: Myth of Myrrha (transformed to myrrh tree, wept resin tears). Medicine for wounds.
greek.significance: Suffering transformed to healing. Beauty (Adonis) born from tears of shame.

description: Myrrh is a figure from ancient mythology.
